lessonTitle: Class II (Intransitive) and Class III (Medial) Verbs

exercises.title: Identifying Verb Classes
exercises.instructions: Identify whether each verb is Class I (transitive), Class II (intransitive), or Class III (medial).

questions.question: ვირბინ [virbin] 'I run' - Which verb class?
questions.explanation: ვირბინ [virbin] 'I run' is Class II because it has no direct object - running is an intransitive action. Class II verbs always keep Nominative alignment.

questions.question: ვხედავ კატას [vkhedav kat'as] 'I see the cat' - Which verb class?
questions.explanation: ვხედავ კატას has a direct object (კატას 'the cat'), so it's Class I (transitive). Transitive verbs shift from Nominative to Ergative in Series II/III.

questions.question: ჩემს ვიცვამ [chems vitsvam] 'I put on (myself)' - Which verb class?
questions.explanation: ჩემს ვიცვამ is Class III (medial) because it's a reflexive-like verb that uses special alignment (Dative subject agreement). Class III verbs have unique patterns.

questions.question: მოვდივარ [movdivar] 'I come' - Which verb class?
questions.explanation: მოვდივარ 'I come' is Class II (intransitive) because motion verbs like 'come' don't take direct objects. The subject will always stay Nominative.

exercises.title: Case Alignment in Different Series
exercises.instructions: Determine whether the subject takes Nominative or Ergative case based on verb class and series.

questions.question: In Series II (Aorist), what case does the subject take for Class II verbs?
questions.explanation: Class II verbs always use Nominative case for subjects, even in Series II (Aorist) and Series III (Perfect). Only Class I transitive verbs shift to Ergative in past tenses.

questions.question: მე ვირბინე [me virbine] 'I ran' - What case is მე in?
questions.explanation: მე is Nominative because ვირბინე [virbine] 'I ran' is Class II (intransitive). Even though it's in Series II (Aorist), Class II verbs never take Ergative case.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly shows Class II verb case marking?
questions.explanation: Option (a) is correct. ბავშვი [bavshvi] is Nominative because ირბინა [irbina] is Class II (intransitive). Class II verbs always keep Nominative subjects, even in Series II.

questions.question: Compare: მე ვირბინე [me virbine] 'I ran' vs მე ვნახე კატა [me vnakhe kat'a] 'I saw the cat'. Why is მე Nominative in the first but Ergative in the second?

options.text: The first is Class II (intransitive), so Nominative. The second is Class I (transitive in Series II), so Ergative.
Both should be Ergative in Series II

questions.explanation: The verb class determines case marking. ირბინებს [irbinebs] 'runs' is Class II (no object) → always Nominative. ვნახე [vnakhe] 'I saw' with object კატა is Class I (transitive in Series II) → Ergative.

exercises.title: Classifying Common Verbs
exercises.instructions: Classify each verb as Class I, II, or III. Then indicate the case the subject will take in Series II.

questions.question: მიდის [midis] 'goes' - Class: _____, Subject case in Series II: _____
questions.explanation: მიდის is Class II (intransitive motion verb). Class II subjects always stay Nominative, even in Series II.

questions.question: ხედავს კატას [khedavs kat'as] 'sees the cat' - Class: _____, Subject case in Series II: _____
questions.explanation: ხედავს has a direct object (კატას), so it's Class I (transitive). In Series II, Class I transitive subjects take Ergative case.

questions.question: დგას [dgass] 'stands' - Class: _____, Subject case in Series II: _____
questions.explanation: დგას 'stands' is Class II (intransitive state verb). Class II verbs always keep Nominative subjects.

questions.question: იცვამს [itsvams] 'puts on (oneself)' - Class: _____, Subject case pattern: _____
questions.explanation: იცვამს is Class III (medial/reflexive verb). Class III verbs use special alignment patterns, often with Dative subject agreement.

exercises.title: Matching Verbs to Their Classes
exercises.instructions: Match each verb to its correct class and alignment pattern.

leftItems.text: ვხედავ კატას [vkhedav kat'as] 'I see the cat'

rightItems.text: Class I: Nom → Erg in Series II

questions.explanation: ვირბინ and მოვდივარ are Class II (intransitive) - always Nominative. ვხედავ კატას is Class I (transitive) - shifts to Ergative in Series II. ჩემს ვიცვამ is Class III (medial) - special alignment pattern.

exercises.title: Class III Special Patterns
exercises.instructions: Answer questions about Class III (medial) verb characteristics and patterns.

questions.question: What makes Class III verbs special compared to Class I and II?

options.text: They have unique alignment patterns that don't follow the standard Nom → Erg shift

questions.explanation: Class III verbs have special alignment patterns - they may use Dative subject agreement or other unique patterns that don't follow the standard Class I (Nom → Erg) or Class II (always Nom) patterns.

questions.question: How should you approach learning Class III verbs?

options.text: Memorize them individually and their specific alignment patterns
Apply the same rules as Class I
They all follow one simple pattern

questions.explanation: Class III verbs are less common and often need to be memorized individually because they have unique alignment patterns that don't follow the standard rules of Class I or Class II.
